instruction: How does the accuracy of support vector machine (SVM) regression algorithms compare to partial least squares (PLS) in determining soil organic matter and particle size using vis-NIR spectroscopy, and how does the size of the calibration set influence this accuracy?
Output:
The accuracy of support vector machine (SVM) regression algorithms was compared to partial least squares (PLS) in determining soil organic matter (SOM) and particle size using vis-NIR spectroscopy. The study found that the SVM-RBF (radial basis function) models showed a significant improvement in accuracy compared to PLS for sand and clay determinations when the calibration set contained at least 1000 samples. This resulted in a reduction of -14-29% in the root mean square error of prediction (RMSEP).

For SOM determinations, the difference in RMSEP values between SVM-RBF and PLS became significant when the calibration set contained 2000 or more samples. In this case, the SVM-RBF models showed a reduction of -8-22% in RMSEP values compared to PLS.

The size of the calibration set had an influence on the accuracy of both SVM and PLS models. Increasing the number of samples in the calibration set improved the performance of both models. However, the PLS models showed a loss of performance for large calibration sets, with between 20 and 27% of the external validation set (1173-2241 samples) being considered outliers and excluded by the PLS regression models.
